status_message:
A humiliating experience!

A video has surfaced online showing staff at a Chinese bank being publicly spanked for poor performance.

The incident took place at a rural commercial bank in Changzhi, northern China, according to the country's official People's Daily newspaper. The Beijing Times said two executives from a Chinese bank have been suspended.

The video appears to have been taken by someone in the audience on a smartphone.

It shows four rounds of spanking, with one woman recoiling each time, apparently in pain.

The person who did the spanking was reported to be a course trainer.  The man later issued a public apology.

However, the incident has sparked outrage online.  

"When I first saw this, I thought it was another cheap public relations stunt from a bank but I can't believe this is real," said one Weibo user.

"This is nothing but degrading and it's so obscene to watch, where are the leadership values?"

Others called for harsh punishment for the bank.

"Expose this rotten company and the awful leadership it claims to possess. This company should be closed down if it thinks it can get away with treating its employees like that."

"#HelloChina" —Feng Shui

Feng Shui is a system of ancient Chinese knowledge, which is mainly used to orient dwellings and tombs. It helps pick locations, directions and designs. Some people believe Feng Shui is capable of affecting the fate of a family and future of younger generations. 

Feng Shui is related to astronomy and geography and directly connected with traditional Chinese philosophies such as tai chi and the octagonal diagram.

The main concept of Feng Shui is about the harmony between man and nature. Feng Shui studies consider basic conditions: heaven, earth, wind, and water, what human beings rely on to survive. Therefore, people must remain in harmonious contact with them.

"#HelloChina" –Spring Festival

Spring Festival or Lunar New Year, is the most important festival for the Chinese people. 

Celebrations begin on Chuxi, or the eve of Lunar New Year. This date changes every year according to the lunar calendar, usually occurring in late January or February. The last evening of the lunar year is a time when all members of the family gather, put up couplets of New Year's wishes on the front door or gateposts, light firecrackers, and enjoy dinner together. Many stay up until midnight and make dumplings for the coming days, a tradition aimed at celebrating the beginning of a new year.

The second day of Spring Festival celebrations is Lunar New Year's Day, when people visit relatives and friends to wish each other a happy and rewarding new year.

A race for EVs only!

An OECD and the International Energy Agency (IEA) report shows that in 2015, the sale of electric cars in China surpassed the United States – an estimated 210,000 electric vehicles were sold in China compared to 110,000 in the US.
link_name: Electric Car Race Held in China

Surge in Chinese students studying at Spanish universities

22% of foreign students are Chinese at Complutense University, the second best university in Spain. As Latin America and China become friendlier, learning Spanish is seen by Chinese students as a valuable skill to get a good job in the future. Further, studying in Spain can actually be cheaper than studying at some prestigious Chinese universities. 

In 2007, China and Spain signed the "academic recognition of studies agreement" allowing any university degree from either country to be recognized automatically by both governments. Further, Spain recognizes Chinese university entrance exams. 

However, life for Chinese students trying to adapt to a different culture can be tough, especially if their Spanish skills are low when first arriving in Spain. However programs like BUDDY, a cultural and language exchange involving Spanish students volunteering to help Chinese students at Complutense university is beneficial not only for the Chinese students, but also for the Spanish students to learn about Chinese culture as well.
link_name: Surge of Chinese Students in Spain

status_message:
"#HelloChina"-Beijing Opera

Beijing Opera, also known as the Peking Opera, is a complicated stage art which combines performance, acrobatics, music, facial painting, and other features into a single unique art form. 
Originating in the Chinese capital Beijing, the art form has a history spanning some 200 years.
Before the advent of Beijing Opera, Kunqu opera was the most prominent form. However, Emperor Qianlong of the Qing Dynasty was not content with this old style.
That's when Beijing Opera came into being, which had drawn many elements and aesthetic principles from various local operas across China.
Beijing Opera has four major roles: Sheng, Dan, Jing and Chou. Sheng is the main male role while Dan refers to female role. Jing is the male role with face-paint, and Chou not only has face-paint but also with a small patch of white chalk around the nose.
The renowned Beijing Opera artist Mei Lanfang was famous for his Dan portrayals, which is actually a female role.
He was one of the greatest popularizes of the opera abroad in the 1920s.
Now you can find the opera's presence not only in China, but also around the world. This uniquely Chinese art-form has spread widely overseas, including in many communities of Chinese abroad.

#HelloChina –Kong Zi, known as #Confucius, was a Chinese educator and thinker who lived over 2,000 years ago.

He was marked as the first teacher who advocated education for commoners. He established Confucianism which emphasizes li (propriety), yue (music) and ren (benevolence). He also advocated running state affairs with morality and etiquette.

After his death, his disciples organized his teachings into 'The Analects', which became the sutra of all schools of Confucianism.

At present, there are over 600 Confucius Institutes and Confucius classes set up in more than 90 countries and regions, which are devoted to teaching Chinese language and introducing Chinese culture.

The first Chinese student speaks at Harvard's commencement!

He Jiang, a doctoral student in biology at #Harvard University, was chosen by the prestigious university as the representative of postgraduates at the commencement.

He Jiang was born in a small village in central China's Hunan Province. Starting with a story of being treated by the folk remedy after being bitten by a poisonous spider when he was in middle school, He Jiang said: "By using the science we already have, we could probably bring my village and thousands like it into the world you and I take for granted every day. And that's an impact every one of us can make."

"Education can change a person's life as it can bring a person from one world to another," he told China Youth Daily. "People living in Chinese rural areas often believe that it's useless to study and children from humble families are almost impossible to make achievements in their careers. However, I cannot agree with those opinions."
link_name: First Chinese student speaks at Harvard's commencement

Chinese man uses bamboo instead of boat as his river commute.

Meet Fang Shuyun, the man who has mastered the skill of floating on the river using a pair of moso bamboo.

Photos of Fang drifting on Fuchun River in Hangzhou, east China's Zhejiang Province, went viral recently, with many people relating the scene to the legendary Qinggong – a technique in China's martial arts novels whose master could glide on water surface using his power.

With the help of two seven-meter-long bamboo poles, the 51-year-old Hangzhou local surfed hundreds of meters at a speed of 30 to 50 meters a minute in front of reporters from Zhejiang Online.

Fang first tried the stunt in 2014 when he missed his ride home one evening and discovered a bamboo shoot floating on the river by accident. Naturally, he fell into water the first time, but he continued to practice until he managed to balance his 1.7-meter-tall, 55-kilogram body on the slippery bamboo.

The key technique, Fang said, is to comply with the wind and water's powers rather than fighting against them.
link_name: Chinese man uses bamboos, not boats, as his river commute

An escaped ostrich dashed down the roads of China's Foshan city on Wednesday startling drivers. Local police received reports of a wayward ostrich by commuters.

Video footage aired by China's state broadcaster CCTV showed the bird running and then being captured by local people.

A local newspaper later reported two ostriches were on the run that day in the city located in south China's Guangdong province, but both birds died. The ostriches belonged to a resident who had bought 9 from a local market.
link_name: Escaped Ostrich Races against Cars in Southern China

Find out how a female driver stranded in her flooded car was rescued last week in east China's Jiangsu Province!

After colliding with a black sedan, the woman's red car knocked down the guardrails and ran into a river after mistakenly stepping on the accelerator instead of the brake, according to Suzhou City traffic police.

Two staff members of a nearby hotpot restaurant rushed to the site of accident after hearing the crash sound, only to find that the woman had been trapped in a car deep in water. 

The day after the rescue, the four rescuers received honorary awards for their brave behavior.

A baby who suffers from anoxia on the train is saved by a passenger who is a nurse.

The baby was born with congenital heart disease and its parents bought the wrong oxygen inhaler for it. Without proper equipment for breathe in oxygen, the baby shows great difficulty in breathing.

Su Shan, a nurse who happens to also be traveling on the train, immediately makes an oxygen inhaler suitable for the baby, saving it from anoxia.

Now the baby is in hospital and in stable condition.

A 25-year-old Chinese student Leng Mengmei was confirmed murdered after disappearing from a shopping trip last Thursday in Australia.

The Australian Police have arrested and charged a 27-year-old man over the death of Leng.

The suspect is believed to be known to the victim.

Police say Leng was found with multiple stab wounds in her neck, and they believe she suffered a violent attack before her body was dumped.

Police also released the surveillance video through their official Facebook.

Leng's disappearance had attracted serious attention among the Chinese community in Australia, before her body was found at Snapper Point, an isolated area frequented by tourists and rock fisherman.

status_message:
GIB CEO on New Infrastructure Credit Rating Methodology

China's credit rating agency Dagong launched a credit rating methodology, the Dagong Global Infrastructure Credit Rating Methodology, which it developed in association with Switzerland-based Global Infrastructure Basel, or GIB.
The companies say the newly launched methodology is more comprehensive than the existing ones, monitoring a project from the very beginning of its design rather than merely focus on its operation. 
 
For a detailed look at the new rating system, CRI's Tu Yun talked to GIB CEO Hans-Peter Egler on the sidelines of the Global Infrastructure Investment and Financing Forum held in Beijing on April 8th.
https://www.facebook.com/globalinfrastructurebasel
link_name: Interview with GIB CEO Hans-Peter Egler

The EUNIC Europe Project includes 11 workshops, aimed at teaching youngsters in Beijing through presentations and other activities about the cultures of EU member states.The topics will cover their traditions, music, literature, visual arts and even food. Internet Moguls Meet, discussing economy and unemployment in Chinese, switches to English later under the request of one mogul Zuckerberg, who apparently needs more time to improve his second language skills. 

Alibaba founder and CEO Jack Ma and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg meet at the China Development Forum in Beijing on Saturday, a time when China's economy faces increasing headwinds, with growth in 2015 the slowest in a quarter of a century.　

Ma admitted that China's economy is currently in its most painful period but he also push for looking on the bright side--unemployment is so far a not big issue in China. 

Zuckerberg agrees, sticking to a more positive note on China's long-term job prospective.

Woman, furious at bus driver, pushes into his seat and slams on the breaks!

Please, don't criticize this woman on a bad day! This irate woman in Changsha, Hunan province, was told by the driver to walk further into the bus to make room for other passengers. After a heated back-and-forth argument with the driver, she tries to squeeze herself into the bus driver's seat and ended up slamming on the breaks.

You can see the scene, as many people were unprepared and fell to the floor, injuring 3 including an old man who falls from his seat into the bus's front door entryway. The bus driver immediately pulled over and called the police. Despite willfully disregarding the safety of the passengers, the woman seemed remorseless. Finally, she was taken into police custody.

status_message:
Lip-syncing Sham Exposed in CCTV Gala

Chinese folk singer Sa Dingding accidentally revealed she was lip-syncing instead of singing during a televised concert by brandishing her microphone the wrong way around.

The 32-year-old singer was performing at the Lantern Festival Gala broadcast on CCTV (China Central Television) when the embarrassing moment occurred. 

A short video clip of the performance has gone viral on the Internet.

The video shows that Sa opened the song with a section of dance, and when she began singing, she suddenly realized she was holding her microphone upside down.

Then Sa smiled sheepishly as she quickly corrected her mistake before carrying on with her performance as if nothing had happened.

After the broadcast ended, Sa mocked herself on Weibo, telling her 1.6 million followers: 'Next time I'll sharpen up my acting skills'.

The scandal has led to criticism of state-owned CCTV for allowing the recorded performance to take place.

A politically active pig escaped his farm and was found near a polling station in Pelham, New Hampshire on Tuesday (February 9), perhaps to cast his ballot in the Granite State's first-in-the-nation presidential primary. 

Social media users captured video of the truant pig wandering amid voters outside the station. 

Police determined that the pig came from a local farm and tried to return him to his owner, but not before being given the runaround by the feisty animal, who seemed determined to perform his civic duty.

Rescue workers are searching the rubble of a collapsed building in Tainan after a powerful, shallow earthquake struck southern Taiwan early Saturday.
At least 13 people were killed and 462 injured when a powerful, shallow earthquake struck southern Taiwan early Saturday, just two days ahead of the traditional lunar New Year.
More than 170 people are still unaccounted for.

Former Israeli President #ShimonPeres has sent New Year greetings to the Chinese people, by dedicating a song he wrote eulogising the friendship of the two peoples.

The song "Chinese Melody" was sung by a Chinese boy and an Israeli girl at a reception in Tel Aviv attended by Shimon Peres and the Chinese ambassador to #Isreal. 

At the reception Peres spoke highly of China's achievements in the past decades and the friendship between China and Israel.

The Chinese Ambassador to Israel Zhan Yongxin expressed appreciation for the efforts and contributions to promoting the relationship between China and Israel made by Shimon Peres. 

At the end of the reception, Peres extended his greetings to all Chinese people.

"Music speaks better than words. Everybody can sing it and you feel that all of us sing together. I wish each of you, and all of you, to enjoy a happy year, a happy future, for a great and a promising China. Xinnian Kuaile! (Happy New Year!) " #springfestival

Liu Xiao Ling Tong was just 26 when he played the part of the Monkey King in the iconic 1986 TV adaptation of the classic novel 'Journey to the West'. The series, telling the epic tale of  the Tang Dynasty Buddhist monk Xuanzang and his pilgrimate to find the sacred texts, in the company of three disciples, a pig demon, a river demon and Sun Wukong the Monkey King.

Now 55, Liu Xiao Ling Tong is now working with the Paramount Pictures to shoot a cinematic version of the classic, bringing the epic tale to new audiences.

Speaking to China Plus, he reveals how he created the role of the mischievous and cunning monkey; the other parts he's played in a long career, and why he thinks the Journey to the West is such a powerful tale.

Pigeon Queen & Her Story

27-year-old Ding Yang is a renowned magician in China. Traditionally, the magic trick involved pigeons coming out one by one, but Ding can pull out the birds in pairs. She is also the only magician in the world who can release 18 pigeons in one show. When she won China's highest-level magic prize last May, stunned audience gave her a nickname "Pigeon Queen".

When Ding was young, her passion was acrobatics instead of magic show. However her waist was badly hurt during a performance in 2006, and she had to leave her beloved acrobatic stage where she had practiced hard for 8 years.

"When you make a spurt towards the summit, you go forward with hope, but when you fall down from the summit, what you get is rebirth." Ding wrote this sentence as her signature on social media. In 2008, she started to learn the magic trick of releasing pigeons. 

Ding has given all her heart and soul into her magic career, and constantly made bold changes in stage props and music in order to improve her performance. Want to have a look? Brace yourself for the miracle!

A pair of robots at a shop in Shanghai is taking the art of making ramen noodles into the 21st century.

A noodle shop in Shanghai has adopted robotics into its noodle creation process. The robots can coordinate precisely with each other from boiling noodles to adding the seasonings and toppings. The accurate cooking time and temperature the robots maintain keeps every bowl of ramen noodles consistent in its taste. The two robots have also been programmed to engage in short conversations in an attempt to entertain the customers.

The official statement also pointed out that the shipping company and local authorities had flaws in their daily management and suggested that 43 people be punished accordingly. #EasternStar

Here are our pick of the TOP 5 Chinese domestic issues in 2015. Our guests shared their views on how they impacted China and its citizens.

Autumn is a fascinating season in Cambodia, an ancient and mysterious country. You could feel it in a recent 2015 China-ASEAN Friendship Concert held in Beijing.

Dok Champa is the national flower of Laos, and the flower with a sweet scent is seen everywhere in Laos.

During the recent 2015 China-ASEAN Friendship Concert in Beijing, Lao singer Kai Overdance performed this household song Champa Flower, which has been sung for more than sixty years.

The concert, themed with "Our Region, Our Song", was initiated by China Radio International. Performers from both China and 10 ASEAN member countries sang their most representative songs.

Thanakha is a yellowish-white cosmetic paste made from ground bark. It is a distinctive feature of the culture of Myanmar, seen commonly applied to the face and sometimes to the arms of women and girls, and is used to a lesser extent also by men and boys.

Myanmar singer A Sai sang the namesake song Thanakha in the recent 2015 China-ASEAN Friendship Concert in Beijing, which was themed with "Our Region, Our Song".

The concert was initiated by China Radio International. Performers from both China and 10 ASEAN member countries sang their most representative songs.

True Love is a classic song in Indonesia. It tells a touching love story between the third president of Indonesia and his wife. 

During the recent 2015 China-ASEAN Friendship Concert in Bejing, Indonesian pop singer Bunga Citra Lestari sang this love song, which deeply moved the audience.

The concert, themed with "Our Region, Our Song", was initiated by China Radio International. Performers from both China and 10 ASEAN member countries sang their traditional songs.

The concert has enhanced understanding between China and ASEAN member countries and helped to create a harmonious atmosphere in the region.

A man believed to be the world's most obese passed away Friday in north Mexico, barely two months after undergoing weight-loss surgery.

Andres Moreno, 38, died of a heart attack and peritonitis (inflammation of the abdominal lining) in Ciudad Obregon, in northern Sonora state, his family said.

Moreno, who at one time tipped the scales at 450 kilos, had bariatric surgery on Oct. 28, in central Guadalajara, Jalisco state in midwestern Mexico, in hopes of shedding the excess weight and leading a normal life.

The surgery involved removing three-fourths of his stomach and reshaping what was left into a tube to "prevent him from eating too much," the Medical Daily reported in October.

While the operation was considered a success, the ex-policeman complained of feeling ill on Christmas Eve, "and his family called on firefighters to help stabilize him," state news agency Notimex reported.

Early Christmas Day, he was having difficulty breathing and family members decided to have him taken to the hospital in an ambulance, but he died on the way.

The "Most Obese Man in the World" had shed 100 kilos to be able to undergo the surgical procedure in October.

On Nov. 19, Moreno had emergency surgery at the local State General Hospital (HGE) in Ciudad Obregon, due to severe peritonitis.

He then returned to Guadalajara to convalesce under the supervision of the same medical team as before, and had returned home a few days ago, Notimex said.

status_message:
Every Single Person Has Access to Electricity in China after this Wednesday!

China has realized universal power access when connecting the last remote group of 39,800 people were connected to the national grid.

The lights came on Wednesday in Gomang and Changjiang villages in Qinghai province, the last group nationwide without modern lighting.

The 9,614 households are at an average altitude of more than 4,000 meters in the remote hinterland of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

At the end of 2012, China had 2.73 million people without electricity,mainly in #Xinjiang, #Sichuan, #Tibet, #Qinghai, #Gansu and #InnerMongolia. Qinghai had about 470,000 people without power.

After a three-year construction, the people in Qinghai became the last without power.

An artificial intelligence (AI) robot has been firstly "employed" as a weather reporter on Shanghai Dragon TV's live breakfast show. 

The robot named "XiaoIce" is actually a piece of software developed by Microsoft using smart cloud and big data.In the first two days of her work, "XiaoIce" has impressed many with her cute voice. 

According to Microsoft, breakthroughs in text-to-speech AI have helped "XiaoIce" to score high points for linguistic naturalness, and hers is closer to the human voice than other speech synthesizers. Through unique emotional technology, she can make comments instantly based on weather data.

Construction has begun on the widest bridge over China's longest river, the Yangtze.

Workers on Wednesday broke ground on the Qingshan Yangtze River Bridge in Wuhan City, capital of central China's Hubei Province. The bridge, the 11th over the Yangtze in Wuhan, will cost about 5.6 billion yuan (865 million U.S. dollars) and is expected to be finished in 2019.

At 47 meters wide, the work is undertaken by the state-owned China Railway Major Bridge Engineering Group Co., Ltd. and will allow trains to pass over the river at 100 km per hour, according to the company.

Local authorities plan another two bridges over the river in the next five years.

Wang Yunle is a 9-year-old pupil in Ningbo, east China's Zhejiang province. She is skilled at playing Guzheng, a traditional Chinese musical instrument known as the Chinese zither.

When Wang was only three, she started to learn Guzhen from her mom, a professional Guzhen teacher. Through years of hard practice, Wang has become a master at such an early age.

The video shows Wang performing a piece called Little Apple. It is adapted from the namesake song that went viral on the Chinese mainland last year.

The central bank on Tuesday announced plans to introduce green bonds to allow financial institutions to raise funds for green projects.

The People's Bank of China (PBOC) said the green bond will widen financing channels for projects in clean energy and environment protection.

The bank stressed that the funds should only be used to support green projects, with strict information disclosure and independent assessment.

China Food and Drug Administration announced on Tuesday that a credit rating system will be introduced into the food and drug industries.

All enterprises in the food and drug industries will be rated as A, B, C or D, respectively, in accordance with a national standard. The rating of C refers to lack of credit worthiness while D means an acute shortage of credit worthiness.

According to the guideline, food and drug businesses with bad credit ratings will be harshly punished and such information about their credit standing will be made public in time.

A 17-year-old foreign teenager has been named as the perpetrator of explicit graffiti on the Shanghai subway.

Passengers on Line 9 of the Shanghai subway were shocked to see the drawings in a carriage on Saturday. The picture was of a naked man, sitting cross-legged and with arms crossed, with streaks of red paint making it as though he was bleeding.

After being reported by some passengers, the Shanghai subway authorities started an investigation and managed to track down the teenager using surveillance camera footage yesterday afternoon.

The teenager has been criticized for breaking Shanghai Railway Management Regulations, and has been told to never break the rules again. Meanwhile, his parents have been asked to pay for the scene to be cleaned up.

Japan Kanji Aptitude Testing Association announced in Kyoto on Tuesday that the Chinese character or kanji meaning "safety" was selected as kanji of the year which best summarizes the year's national mood in Japan, local media reported. 

According to the Kyoto-based organization, the selection was based on votes cast by the general public. The character meaning "safety" won 5,632 of the 129,647 votes received in total this year and was chosen as kanji of the year.

In September, Abe administration forced through the upper house of the parliament the controversial security-related bills despite strong protests from the Japanese people. People are concerned about safety issues as the risks of Japan being involved in a war or suffering from terrorist attacks have significantly increased. 

The kanji-of-the-year selection event has been held annually since 1995. Last year, the character meaning "tax" was chosen as the consumption tax rate had been raised from 5 percent to 8 percent.

"Bitter" becomes 2015 Chinese character in Malaysia.

A poll of 14 thousand Malaysians across the world has chosen Ku, meaning bitter, as the most popular Chinese character of 2015. 

Fang Tianxing, President of the Federation of Chinese Associations Malaysia, said the results showed the public dissatisfaction with the country's new consumption tax policy, soaring commodity prices and currency depreciation. 

Malaysia started the annual poll in 2011. South Korea, Japan, and Singapore also hold similar character polls each year.

A performance by two art troupes from the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) cannot be staged as scheduled due to communication issues at the working level, according to relevant departments on Saturday.

China attached high importance to the cultural exchanges with the DPRK, and was ready to continue to work with it to promote the bilateral exchanges and cooperation in culture and all other areas, a press release from the departments said.

The two troupes -- the State Merited Chorus and the Moranbong Band -- were scheduled to perform in the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing from Dec. 12 to 14.

The historic Paris agreement on climate change was finally adopted with no objection on Saturday by the 196 Parties of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) during the 21st session of the Conference of the Parties (COP21) hosted by France.

"The Paris Climate Conference is a crucial point in the global climate governance process. The outcome has a bearing with the undertaking of climate change of the human being and our future of sustainable development," China's Special Representative on Climate Change Xie Zhenhua said after the adoption of the Paris agreement.

Xie stressed that China, as a responsible developing country, will take international obligations commensurate with its own national condition, development stage and actual capacity.

"Although the agreement is not perfect, it does not stop us from moving a historical step forwards," Xie said, calling on developed countries to abide by their promises to provide finance, technology development and transfer, and capacity building to developing countries.

"China is willing to work together with all Parties, in accordance with the principles of the UNFCCC, towards implementing the Paris Agreement and establishing a global climate governance system for win-win cooperation," Xie affirmed.

UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said "what was once unthinkable is now unstoppable", referring to the historic Paris agreement on climate change.

"For the first time, every country in the world has pledged to curb emissions, strengthen resilience and join in common cause to take climate action," Ban said, adding that "the Paris agreement demonstrates solidarity."

"You have concluded not just any agreement, it is an ambitious, universal and legally binding agreement," French President Francois Hollande told the ministers and negotiators from the 196 Parties of the UNFCCC.

"There is no progress with risks, no progress without ordeals. History is written by those who engage, not by those who calculate," he added.

The French head of state also promised that "France will put everything in place to implement the agreement."

"This agreement, we had been waiting for a long time, for 40 years," Hollande said.

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry sees the Paris agreement as "a victory for all the planet and the future generations".

For the executive secretary of the UNFCCC Christiana Figueres, "It is an agreement of conviction, of solidarity, of long term vision."

The Paris agreement runs to 32 pages with 29 articles, including objective, mitigation, adaptation, loss and damage, finance, technology development and transfer, capacity building, and transparency of action and support.

On the basis of equity and common but differentiated responsibilities and respective capabilities, the Paris agreement calls for aiming to hold global average temperature rise to below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and strives for limiting the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

Taking into account of the needs and priorities of developing countries, the agreement also eyes 100 billion U.S. dollars a year by developed countries for developing countries from 2020.

The 21st session of the Conference of the Parties of the UNFCCC kicked off on Nov. 30, 2015.

Shortly after the adoption of the climate pact, U.S. President Barack Obama on Saturday called the Paris agreement "a turning point for the world," saying it had created an "enduring framework" for future efforts.

Meanwhile in Europe, the Finnish government praised the climate change agreement, while Finnish environmentalists emphasized the challenges remaining.

Finnish Minister for the Environment Kimmo Tiilikainen described the Paris agreement as "a turning point", but noted that it is not perfect.

Finnish Prime Minister Juha Sipila said Finland wants the agreement to bring a fast change with an impact.

An inspirational act was spotted on an airplane, when a young stewardess fed a senior man who was having trouble holding a spoon.

The flight departed from Zhengzhou, capital of Henan province on December 8, 2015. The old man surnamed Niu, was heading to Hainan's tropical city Sanya to spend the winter.

As a retired medical professor from central Henan's Xinxiang, the 71-year-old Niu was using a wheelchair to board the airplane because he became disabled by a cerebral injury in 2013.

Noticed by Fan Xuesong,a stewardess of Hainan Airlines, she arranged a front row seat for his convenience, allowing him to use the toilet and take care of himself more easily.

When giving out dinner boxes, Fan found the old man's right hand was trembling while holding the spoon. She went over and checked on the man but he could only respond with slurring. She then volunteered to feed him.

The old man burst into tears when Fan told him "That's alright; let me help you with your food."
The stewardess also changed his rice box for a noodles box after noticing the old man having difficulty chewing.

The scene was captured by a passenger on board and later it went viral on the internet soon after it getting its way onto Chinese social media site Weido.com.

On arrival, Niu expressed his appreciation to Miss Fan through texting.

A sharp rise in online searches for masks and air purifiers on smoggy days is expected;however, a boom in the sales of condoms and sportswear might be surprising for most. 

According to research results from one of China's largest online shopping platform Taobao.com, the number of searches for condoms has increased in the last week, correlating with some of the worst smog seen in northern China this year. 

As smog hit Beijing and some other northern Chinese cities, orders for condoms in these cities outnumbered those in cities with cleaner air, as people are concerned about the quality of their childbearing and attempt to prevent pregnancies on smoggy days. 

Interest in sportswear also increased during the heavy smog, as people tend to have stronger desires to exercise outside once the air becomes cleaner. Sales of sportswear have surpassed those of women's apparel and cosmetics on smoggy days. 

Vendors of anti-pollution products might profit the most from the smog. During last week, searches for anti-pollution masks on Taobao.com surged 116% compared with the week before.

An unusual rock song stormed Chinese social media this week.
The song, I'll Show You Some Color, was performed by pop singer Tan Weiwei, with a homegrown Lao Qiang band from a remote village in Northwest China. 
Lao Qiang means "old tune". It originated some 2,000 years ago in Hua Yin village and is considered "a living fossil" of Chinese rock music. The song has won wide critical acclaim for its combination of Chinese folk and western rock and roll. 
Here's a part of the lyrics: 
Why's there no more oasis in the desert? 
Why're there no more twinkling stars at night? 
Why do flowers stop blooming?
Why does the world lose its color?
Why do we squander when we know what's coming after?
We need to stop and give the colors back to the world.
link_name: Unusual rock song stormed Chinese social media

A red alert, the highest level for smog danger, is set to take effect in Beijing tomorrow morning.

Starting at 7am on Tuesday, an odd-even license plate restriction will be imposed on all vehicles in the city.

Industrial production will also be curtailed further, and further restrictions on schools may also take effect.

This is the first time since the 4-tiered color-coded smog system was brought in a few years ago that the condition has been brought to red in Beijing.

This come as the heavy smog has returned to the capital region after a couple of days reprieve. 

As 6pm this Monday, PM2.5-levels across Beijing are averaging around 240.

Levels higher than 200 are defined as heavy pollution by Beijing's environmental protection bureau. 

As such, schools were told to keep their students indoors today.

The capital has already seen a reduction of industrial activity.

Forecasters are suggesting the smog is going to linger in the greater-Beijing area until at least Thursday, with rain expected to clear the air at that point.

Coal fired power plants are the major culprit at this point.

This comes as politicians in Paris continue talks on bringing together a global emission reduction plan this week at the UN Climate Change talks.

Here in China, plans are already in-place to reduce emissions of major pollutants in the power sector by 60 percent by 2020, with emissions to peak by 2030.

A male runner, 33, has died while taking part in a marathon event in Shenzhen, a coastal city adjacent to Hongkong, China, organizers announced on Saturday.

According to the statement from the event organizers, a male runner surnamed Yao collapsed suddenly just 400 meters away from the finish line in the 13.1-mile half marathon race on Saturday.

"The ambulance medical staff were just across the street and witnessed the falling of Yao, offering him an immediate medical care," said the statement.

"It's found that Yao's eyes had rolled back, totally unconscious, when the medical came up to give assistance. The ECG monitor indicated the symptom of ventricular fibrillation on the ambulance, so the medical workers carried out an emergency treatment including defibrillation on the way to hospital."

"The ambulance reached the People's Hospital of Nanshan District in about 15 minutes, but the doctors failed to save Yao's life at last," added the statement.

It's not the first time for Yao to run marathon. It's learned from Yao's acquaintances, Yao had plenty of experiences in running marathon and he just took part in a local half marathon last month, timing two hours 10 minutes. Yao had a time of two and half hours when the accident happened this time, which seemed not to be quite challenging for him.

There were four death accidents happening in marathon running last year in China out of a total of around 50 races, the statistics from China track & field association revealed. 

It's not rare to see marathon running death. In September, a 42-year-old runner died on the last mile at the Great North Run in Newcastle of England.

Hazardous smog is expected to engulf Beijing and its neighbouring areas again, starting from today.

The smog prompted Beijing to upgrade its alert level to the second-highest for the first time and triggered the suspension of most industrial production. 

Vehicle exhaust emissions, coal-fired power generation and winter heating have been blamed for most of the pollution in northern China.

Sang Lan, a former Chinese star gymnast, has once again become the focus of media coverage.

Sang was left paralyzed after being injured at the New York Goodwill Games in 1998.

At the time, she accused a Romanian coach of distracting her as she was making a warm up vault. 

A report from China's official Xinhua News Agency has now cast doubt on Sang's story, saying new evidence has suggested the foreign coach did not distract her. Instead, he was the first person to offer help to Sang after she lost balance and fell onto the mat.

Responding to the report, Sang Lan wrote on her Weibo account that some people had jumped to a conclusion simply based on some screenshots.

She suggested these people interview those who witnessed the incident. 

Sang was only 17 when she was injured, and has had to use a wheelchair ever since.

The gymnast had been hailed as a hero and a smiling angel, and for the positive outlook and stubbornness she displayed during the long process of recovery.

However, in 2011, she launched a transnational lawsuit against the organizing committee of the Goodwill Games, demanding huge compensation, prompting some to doubt her credibility.

A clothing store that goes by the name of "ISIS" in shenzhen city in south China's Guangdong Province has come to the attention of the local police. 

It comes after the recent terror attacks in Paris raised public awareness of the Islamic State terrorist group, which is often abbreviated to "ISIS". 

After a thorough investigation by the police department, it was confirmed that the clothing store had nothing to do with the terrorist group. The store owner said the name was supposed to sound like the Chinese word "meaning". 

The local police have strongly recommended that the clothing store dismantle the signboard as quickly as possible and rename the store to avoid misunderstanding.

Chinese President Xi Jinping has requested breakthroughs in reform of the country's armed forces by 2020, vowing to reorganize the current military administration structure and military command areas.

Xi, also chairman of the Central Military Commission, made the remarks at a meeting on reforming the armed forces which was held from Nov. 24 to 26.

An overall structure should be formed to empower the Central Military Commission to be in charge of both administration and command of the People's Liberation Army (PLA). It will create battle command zones to focus on combat. Different services commanders will be expected to focus on development of their respective services, Xi said.

The structural reform aims to better integrate the command over the PLA, Xi said.

China's last foot binding survivors are becoming extinct!

Suffering for beauty is a concept familiar to most women who have dressed little to stay stylish in cold weather, squeezed their feet into uncomfortable high heels, or even surgically altered their faces and figures. 

In ancient China, millions of women went even further – binding their feet so that they could be dubbed "three-inch golden lotuses". (The ideal length for a bound foot was 3 Chinese inches, and it was considered a symbol of "extreme beauty" back then.) 

Although foot binding was banned in 1912, some still continued the inhuman practice in secret. Nowadays, women with bound feet are numbered. 

Click the video to find out more.

Chinese Premier Li Keqiang on Sunday raised a five-pronged proposal to uphold and promote peace and stability in the South China Sea, calling on countries outside the region to refrain from taking actions that may cause tension in the region.

First, all countries make the commitment to observing the purposes and principles of the UN Charter, defend the outcome of WWII and post-war order, cherish hard-won peace and jointly safeguard peace and stability in the world and the region, including in the South China Sea, said Li. 

Second, sovereign countries directly concerned undertake, in accordance with universally recognized principles of international law, including UNCLOS of 1982, to peacefully settle sovereign and jurisdictional disputes through friendly consultation and negotiation, said Li. 

Third, China and ASEAN countries commit themselves to full and effective implementation of the Declaration on the Conduct of Parties in the South China Sea (DOC) in its entirety, accelerate consultations to strive for early conclusion of a full code of conduct (COC) on the basis of consensus, and take steps to improve regional mechanisms for mutual trust and cooperation, said Li. 

Fourth, countries from outside the region undertake to respect and support the efforts by countries in the region to uphold peace and stability in the South China Sea, play a positive and constructive role and refrain from taking actions that may cause tension in the region, he added. 

Fifth, all countries undertake to exercise and uphold the freedom of navigation and overflight in the South China Sea in accordance with international law, he concluded. 

The Chinese premier arrived in Malaysia on Friday for the 18th ASEAN-China (10+1) leaders' meeting, the 18th ASEAN-China, Japan and South Korea (10+3) leaders' meeting, and the 10th East Asia Summit.

During his four-day stay in Malaysia, he is also to pay his first official visit to the country since taking office in March 2013.  #LiKeqiang #Malaysia

Beijing has enhanced its security and anti-terrorism response with heavier police presence and stricter checks on parcels, Beijing Public Security Bureau said Saturday.

The Chinese capital raised its security level on Nov. 15, two days after the Paris terrorist attacks, according to a source with the bureau. 

More police have been mobilized across the city, and more stringent checks will be imposed on courier services, large events and public transportation.

An emergency security conference was called on Nov. 15, during which Police Chief Guo Shengkun, who also heads the national counterterrorism leading group, underscored the need to heighten awareness and boost preventative measures.

Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday strongly condemned the terrorist attack at a hotel in the Malian capital of Bamako, during which at least 27 people were killed including three Chinese nationals.

In his statement, Xi Jinping also expressed his deepest sympathy and condolences to the families of the victims of this latest attack.

He also noted that China would work with the International community to fight against such horrifying terrorist attacks and help maintain world peace and stability.

At the same time, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang also expressed condolences to the victims' families and called for intensified efforts to effectively safeguard the safety and legal rights of Chinese nationals and institutions abroad.

Earlier, the Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who is currently in Kuala Lumpur, said he was deeply saddened to hear that three Chinese citizens were killed in the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako.

Wang strongly condemned the atrocity and said China would work with the International community to fight against terrorism.

Meanwhile, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hong Lei also expressed indignation at the Malian hotel attack.

He added that the Chinese Foreign Ministry and the Chinese Embassy in Mali had launched an emergency-response mechanism immediately and had conducted rescue operations.

Hong Lei also confirmed that four Chinese nationals had been rescued.

Chinese man dies of 'drinking too much cola'
Cola addicts, take note: too much of carbonated drinks could cost you your life.
In a recent incident in China, doctors have blamed the death of a 20-year-old man on cola. Zhejiang-based Qianjiang Evening News identified the man as a Mr. Wang on Thursday and doctors say his death is linked to "drinking too much cola."
According to the report, his blood sugar had shot up to 96.56 mmol/L — nearly 20 times higher than the normal range which is between 3.9 and 6.1 mmol/L. He was also diagnosed with liver and kidney failure.
Wang was rushed to a local hospital in east China's Ningbo city after developing nausea and vomiting for a couple of days, but died on Monday.
"He suffered from diabetes ketoacidosis, one of the most dangerous complications of diabetes," said doctors, adding, "He must have had diabetes earlier, but didn't take any measures because he [thought he] was young."
Wang reportedly drank more than 10 bottles of the carbonated drink every day.
Doctors remind that people with diabetes should avoid drinking large amounts of carbonated beverage in a short period of time to prevent complications from the disease. Diabetes ketoacidosis, with high mortality, often strikes the patients suddenly and develops rapidly, said doctors.
According to data from the International Diabetes Federation (IDF), there are approximately 382 million adult diabetics in the world, with China at the top. Although the disease used to be prevalent only among the elderly, more and more young people are diagnosed with the disease in recent years due to unhealthy dietary habits.

Chinese Premier Li Keqiang has said China and Malaysia, standing at a new starting point for development in relations, should continue to view and grow bilateral ties from a strategic perspective.

Over the past 40 years, cooperation between China and Malaysia has set a good example of friendly exchanges between countries in the region, Li said in a signed article published Friday by major Malaysian newspapers ahead of his trip to the Southeast Asian nation. Last year marked the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

"I am no stranger to this beautiful country, as I visited Malaysia in 1996 when the Twin Towers of Kuala Lumpur were just completed," Li said, noting that Malaysia has witnessed impressive and admirable achievements in the past two decades.

Hailing the achievements China and Malaysia have made in interactions in politics, economy and people-to-people exchanges, he said the two countries' development strategies have much in common.

Li noted that as China is advancing the Belt and Road Initiative, encouraging mass entrepreneurship and innovation, and transforming and upgrading its economic structure, Malaysia is also gearing toward all-round economic transformation with the New Economic Model aimed at more robust growth.

"I see this as offering each other a perfect opportunity to boost development," he said.

He called on China and Malaysia to draw on their respective strengths and conduct more cooperation on production capacity.

"We may encourage more enterprises to take part in the development of the industrial parks in Qinzhou and Kuantan, enhance infrastructure building and increase connectivity," Li said. "Such cooperation will produce huge development dividends to ensure steady growth and make life better for our people."

Meanwhile, the Chinese premier said both China and Malaysia have a major role to play in turning East Asia a major pole sustaining steady global growth, adding that China-ASEAN relations are a major cornerstone for peace, stability, development and prosperity in the region.

When talking about the upcoming East Asia leaders' meetings, Li said, "Ours is a time with interwoven traditional and non-traditional security challenges, on top of which external interference has led to incessant turbulences in some parts of the world and caused serious spillover effects."

Countries in the region should cherish the harmonious coexistence of different cultures and development paths, and work together to uphold regional peace and stability for the long run, he said.

In the article, Li also spoke of the story about Zheng He, a Chinese navigator during the Ming Dynasty (the 14-17th century) who came to Malacca for five times on his seven sea voyages.

Zheng's dedication to peace and his readiness to reach out and help others show the very essence of the Chinese philosophy, where peace and good-neighborliness always come first, he said.

"It also constitutes part of the cultural legacy that brings countries of the region together," he added.

The Chinese premier left for Kuala Lumpur Friday for his first official visit to the country since taking office in March 2013. During his four-day stay in Malaysia, he will also attend a series of East Asia leaders' meetings. #LiKeqiang #Malaysia

The number of Chinese mainland students studying in colleges and universities in the U.S. exceeded 300,000 for the first time this academic year, up 10.8%.
It means that Chinese mainland students now account for 31.2% of some 1 million international students in US colleges and universities, followed by India, South Korea, Saudi Arabia and Canada.
International students in all 50 US states contributed more than $30 billion to the US economy in 2014, according to the US Department of Commerce.
That includes $9.8 billion contributed by students from the Chinese mainland.

More Chinese tourists have returned home on flights from #Paris after the terror attacks that killed over 130 people and injured hundreds. 
The first flight, with over 200 passengers on board, landed in  southern China's city of Guangzhou on Sunday morning, while another 3 flights from Paris arrived in Shanghai. 
Stats from the Chinese authority show that nearly 1,300 Chinese tourists were in Paris on Saturday.

The topic of "Genetically modified humans" has lately become one of the most popular hashtags on Chinese social media as some reports say humans who have had their DNA genetically modified could exist within two years.

A US biotech company Editas Medicine plans to become the first lab in the world to "genetically edit" the DNA of patients suffering from some rare inherited eye disease. Scientists in the company believe they can fix the mutated DNA using the ground-breaking technology Crispr.

The company hopes to start trialing the technology on blind patients in 2017. As gene editing is currently banned in the US, the company would need special permission from health regulators.

The news has spread like wild fire in China and become a hot controversial issue which has divided Chinese netizens. Many of them are concerned that the technology may bring lots of social disturbances in the future while others appreciate its great benefits for human beings.
link_name: First GM Humans Could Exist within Two Years

Around 40 years ago, Rong Baozhai purchased a painting for 80 yuan (about 12.5 US dollars). But he never expected this painting will bring him such great fortune four decades later.

The painting, titled as "Mountains in Red" and painted by Chinese artist Li Keran, was sold at 184 million yuan (about 28.9 million US dollars) on Nov. 15, 2015.

Li Keran was a renowned Chinese landscape painter, who was active in the 1950s and 1960s. Li finished the painting "Mountains in Red" during his prime time.

The United States will work with France to hunt down those responsible for the attacks in Paris. President Obama speaking at the G20 Summit in Turkey added that America will increase efforts to eliminate Islamic State in Syria and prevent it from making attacks like those in Paris.

New Zealand model Nela Zisser from Auckland ate 22 Big Macs in just under an hour.
The total weight of the food is 10.6 lbs or 4.8 kg.
She was only 3 burgers short of the world record set by American competitive eater Matt Stonie.
Matt Stonie finished 25 Big Macs within 22 minutes.
French Embassy in China flies a flag at half-mast to pay tribute to victims in Paris attack.

Paris police said there were 4 attackers in the theatre who blew themselves up after shooting some 100 people dead.
The city's prosecutors also revealed that there were at least 7 attackers in the city. They believe that all have been killed.
At least 153 people were dead after shootings and blasts in Paris at Friday night, with more injured.

It is said this is the dealiest attack seen in France since WWII. #parisattack

#OneChildPolicy  Some say that China's one-child policy was originally implemented to boost the economy by reducing the number of mouths to feed. However, others say the economic development would have occurred regardless of any state-mandated social engineering. Which side of the debate are you on? Listen to what TODAY's experts have to say!

Chinese Premier Li Keqiang met with Bill Gates in Beijing on Thursday. Climate change and nuclear energy were on the agenda.

Li said China is ready to work with other nations to address climate change, while calling for Sino-US cooperation to develop safe, affordable and sustainable nuclear energy in China.

Li said China would also support such cooperation in third markets.

Gates echoed Li's sentiments, while praising China's efforts in coping with climate change and developing new energy industries.

[Photo: Xinhua]

Do you know that air purifiers already existed in China in ancient times? Millennia before China's smog made world headlines, Chinese lamp makers were coming up with designs to reduce air pollution, a new discovery has showed.

Chinese archaeologists excavating a noted Western Han Dynasty (206 BC - 24 AD) cemetery in east China's Jiangxi Province have unearthed two 2,000-year-old bronze lamps that can "swallow" smoke.

The lamps are both the shape of a goose catching a fish in its mouth. The light is attached to the fish. Smoke emitted during the burning of wax can enter the bird's body via an intake on the fish, travel through its neck and be dissolved by water stored in its hollow belly, Xin Lixiang, who leads the excavation team, told Xinhua on Thursday.
#G20Summit will be held in Turkey this year? What the main focus of this year's summit? Is the U.S. slowing down the reform pace of the world monetary system? Listen to what our expert says!

China's e-commerce giant Alibaba saw record breaking sales of more than 90 billion yuan, or 14 billion US dollars, on the just concluded Singles Day on Wednesday.

That number is a 60% increase from last year. The company's payment service Alipay processed 117 million transactions during the first hour on Wednesday.

Alibaba stats show this year's orders were placed from 232 countries and regions.

In comparison, Americans spent just 1.5 billion dollars online on last year's Black Friday, the Friday before Thanksgiving – one of the biggest sales days of the year stateside.

An electronic screen shows that the transaction volume of Tmall topping 20 billion yuan (about 3.2 billion dollars) in the first 34 minutes of the Singles Day at the National Aquatics Center in Beijing, capital of China, Nov. 11, 2015. [Photo: Xinhua]

Buy! Buy! Buy! China's "Cyber Monday" Smashes Records

The online sales of Alibaba's T-Mall has surpassed last year's record ($9 billion) within 12 hours on China's biggest annual online shopping festival (11/11, known as the Singles' Day or Double Eleven).
The shopping festival started at midnight and will last an entire 24 hours. Alibaba says it expects to see a peak of 120,000 orders and 60,000 payments per second.
For amusement only

Located on the Svalbard Islands in the Arctic, the Global Seed Vault is home to millions of seeds.

The facility is surrounded by permafrost and is naturally cooled to around -3 degrees Celsius.

The main vault is cooled even further to -18 degrees Celsius to guarantee that crops preserved here can survive for hundreds of years.

Seeds preserved in the vault are duplicates. In other words, they are back-ups in case gene banks fail.

And the vault has already proven its worth.

In September, precious seeds that were originally bred in war-stricken Syria were dispatched to Morocco and Lebanon to be duplicated to reconstitute stocks.

A polar bear sculpture made of ice stands outside the Global Seed Vault in Longyearbyen Feb. 25, 2008. [File Photo: Xinhua]

Chinese collector Liu Yiqian snapped a sensus #Modigliani nude for $170.4 million in New York, setting a new world record price at auction for the Italian artist in a Christie's sale.
"Nu Couche" or "Reclining Nude," painted in 1917-18, sold after a frantic nine-minute bidding war between seven would-be buyers.
The previous record for a Modigliani was $70.7 million set in November 2014 for a sculpture.
It was just $9 million shy of the world record of $179.4 million for Picasso's "The Women of Algiers (Version 0)", sold last May in New York.

The Australian Senate has passes legislations surrounding the China-Australia Free Trade Agreement today, clearing the final hurdle to enact the agreement.
The Customs Amendment (China-Australia Free Trade Agreement) Bill 2015 and the complementary Customs Tariff Amendment (China-Australia Free Trade Agreement) Bill 2015 was approved by the House of Representatives back on October 22, 2015. 
The China-Australia Free Trade Agreement may take act in the end of this year.

China welcomes the smooth ending of Myanmar's general election on Sunday, Foreign Ministry spokesman Hong Lei said Monday.

"As a friendly neighbor of Myanmar, China supports Myanmar in all political agendas after the election in accordance with law so as to realize national stability and long-term development," said Hong at a daily press briefing. 

According to incomplete counting of votes reported by local media, the National League for Democracy (NLD) is leading as winner of the election. #MyanmarElection

To celebrate the occasion, the restaurant has launched a special event where customers are welcome to enjoy cooked crawfish placed on a woman's body and take pictures.

Brave driver risked life driving a blazing truck out of a tunnel
The driver, surnamed Xiao, was driving through a 3.5km long tunnel on a high way in southwest China's Guizhou province, when he found his truck was on fire. He stopped and tried to put out the fire with a fire extinguisher but failed.
Concerned that the blazing truck would explode inside the tunnel, the driver drove the truck out of the tunnel, risking his life in the process. Shortly after, firefighters arrived and put out the fire.

Soldiers across China soon will enjoy aerobics specially designed for them. 
The Chinese army recently issued the first soldier aerobics program.
The 5-minute long aerobics routine combines fighting moves, pop dance and tai chi.
The aerobics was taught in a trial to a dozen troops in Beijing last year. 
Soldiers said it's a suitable recreational activity and fitness exercise for the military as it's easy to learn and can be practiced during training breaks.
The move is part of a training program released in February links soldiers' weight to promotion.
Those failing to meet weight standards might lose the chance of promotion.

Internet searches for products related to pregnancy preparation saw a dramatic increase, up 148 percent, after China announced its plan last week to allow all couples to have two children.
According to data from Alibaba's shopping platforms Taobao and Tmall, people from smaller cities in northern and central China are the most eager to have a 2nd child.
None of the big cities like Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou reached the top 20 cities that generate the highest number of "preparing for pregnancy" searches in the past week.
Pregnancy test kits, ovulation prediction kits and oral folic acid are the most popular products being searched on Alibaba's two platforms.

The World Health Organization (WHO) on Saturday formally declared Sierra Leone "Ebola free."

WHO Resident Representative to Sierra Leone Anders Nordstrom made the announcement after the West African nation has gone for 42 days without recording a single case of the Ebola virus. 

The announcement was made at a ceremony held at the Chinese-built Bintumani Conference Center in Freetown, which was attended by Sierra Leone President Ernest Bai Koroma, UN representatives and foreign diplomats.
A villager in central China's Henan Province has been digging a well for 8 years, and failed to find water. But suddenly he got this: an "underground palace".

Comments by Chinese President Xi Jinping and Taiwan leader Ma Ying-jeou during their summit in Singapore  Saturday afternoon. It is the first meeting between leaders from both sides in 66 years, and has been hailed as a "milestone". #XiJinping #XiVisit #XiMa

A historical handshaking!
Chinese President Xi Jinping and Taiwan leader Ma Ying-jeou has met in Singapore, marking a breakthrough in face-to-face exchange and communication between leaders across the Taiwan Strait after hardships and twists since 1949.
The meeting began at 3 p.m. Saturday at the Shangri-La Hotel in Singapore, with the two leaders shaking hands in front of hundreds of media cameras, followed by a close door meeting.
#XiJinping #XiVisit #XiMa

Xi Jinping and Ma Ying-jeou shook hands on Saturday afternoon in Singapore in the first meeting between leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since 1949, opening up a historic page in cross-Strait relations.

Hundreds of journalists from around the world witnessed the historic moment at the Shangri-La Hotel.  #XiVisit #Xijinping

China Eastern Airlines will become the first domestic carrier to provide a 3G Wi-Fi service on flights in China, starting next week.
The offer will apply to long-haul flights from Shanghai to New York, Los Angeles and Toronto served by Boeing 777-300ER aircraft.
It will also be trialled on international flights to Vancouver and San Francisco and domestic flights to and from Beijing, Guangzhou, Kunming, Chengdu and Chongqing for three months.
Passengers can register for a code on their official website to access the internet services. But the service is only limited to 50 passengers per flight.
While people with access codes will have full access to the Internet, those without will still be able to browse a limited number of websites.

China has regained control of 4.7-square-kilometers of land from Russia as five new boundary markers along the two countries' border were unveiled on Wednesday.

The festival opened with the screening of one of latest Chinese blockbusters "Monkey King - Hero is back."

"Although Swedish films reflect Swedish society and Swedish culture, the stories, feelings and experiences of being human are universal. And just as you can be inspired by us, we can be inspired by you. We look forward to seeing many more Chinese films from all voices from your great country. "

Tianjin University makes 'lung' for China's C919

The Comac C919 is the largest commercial airliner designed and built in China since the defunct Shanghai Y-10. The comfort and environment of the cabin is an important part of the C919. Tianjin University has successfully finished the numerical simulation and optimal design of the air distribution system for the C919, making the air in the cabin 20 percent fresher than regular commercial airliners.

A Hong Kong couple, who are die-hard fans of Mickey Mouse, have been to #Disneyland 1,100 times in 9 years, according to Hong Kong-based newspaper Wen Wei Po.

They have been to Disneyland 132 times already this year, or 13 times per month.

The couple started purchasing the Disneyland annual pass back in 2006. 
They keep two rooms to store all the Mickey Mouse souvenirs and products they've bought, saying Disneyland is part of their life.

They also spend all their significant days, like birthdays, Christmas and New Year's in Disneyland and they've gone to other Disneyland parks in other countries such as Japan, the US and France.

Sichuan food is the spiciest cuisine of all China, but Chinese people are crazily in love with it. You'll know this fact from the flourishing Sichuan food restaurants across the country! A quadruped robot in the southwestern municipality of Chongqing walked its way on to the pages of the Guinness World Records book on Sunday.

"Xingzhe No. 1" was developed by Li Qingdu, a professor with the college of automation under the Chongqing University of Post and Telecommunications. Starting on Oct. 24, it took 340,000 continuous steps over 54 hours covering a distance of 134.03 km and used 0.8 kwh of power.

The previous record was set by Ranger, a quadruped robot developed by Cornell University in America, which walked 65 km in 30 hours consuming 0.5 kwh.

IS Claims Responsibility for Russian Plane Crash in Egypt

An Egyptian IS-affiliated terror group claimed responsibility for the crash of a Russian plane in Egypt's Sinai that took place earlier on Saturday and left no survivors, the group said in a statement on its Twitter account.#RussianPlane

Innards Soup & Sesame Cake Combo

Innards soup may not sound very appetizing, but people in China have been enjoying zasuitang for centuries. Wreckage of the Russian jetliner was found on the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt, RIA Novosti news agency reported Saturday.

An Airbus 320 aircraft en route from Egypt's Sharm El-Sheikh resort city in South Sinai to Russia's St. Petersburg vanished from the radars on Saturday, with over 200 people aboard, Youm7 quoted the Egyptian Ministry of Civil Aviation. 

The airplane took off at 05:51 local time on Saturday morning and disappeared from radar 23 minutes afterwards, the ministry added.

Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said that Russian Embassy in Egypt is checking information and current situations about the airliner which belongs to Russia's Metrojet airline.

Metrojet is an airline based in Kogalym, a town in Russia's western Siberia, that started operations from May of 1993.
A Russian airliner crashed on Saturday in Egypt's restive Sinai Peninsula, Egyptian prime minister's office said.
The sample of the new 100-yuan note.

A new draft law aiming to strengthen the Chinese film industry by cutting red tape for filmmakers and cracking down on piracy, among other measures, was put before China's top legislature on Friday.

The law will revoke some filmmaking permits, simplify the process of regulatory reviews to which prospective scripts are subjected and make it easier to hold film festivals.

Under the draft law, Chinese filmmakers will get incentives in financing, taxation and land use.

Chinese Hamburgers? Yes, Yes, and Yes

Sorry Lord Sandwich, but rou jia mo, also known as the Chinese hamburger, is the oldest snack on record that puts meat between two bits of bread. Originating in Shaanxi Province, it has many variants, such as the mutton version popular in Xi'an's Muslim quarter. In this episode of Eating on Streets of China, William Wang focuses on the Chinese specialties that you don't want to miss.
People read books during 2014 Beijing Book Fair at the Chaoyang Park in Beijing, capital of China, April 11, 2014.
The undated photo shows Hailai Rize, a child welfare tutor, taking care of a left-behind child in Jinyang County in southwest China's Sichuan Province.

How fast can you ride a motorcycle on a civilian road? 
237 km/h, that is the speed recorded by a motorcyclist who took a tour around the 32.7-kilometer-long Second Ring Road in downtown Beijing within only 13 minutes and 43 seconds. The speed limit is 80km/h.
The motorcyclist, surnamed Pang, was obvious too proud of his speed, and uploaded  a video online right after the racing before dawn on Aug. 22, 2015.
The video shows Pang riding an R1 Yamaha motor without license plate. Pang also changed lane many times to overtake other cars.
Police tracked him down and detained him in his hometown in southern China, 
He has been sentenced to three months of detention and a fine of 3000 yuan with the charge of dangerous driving on Friday.

New Family Planning Policy to Benefit China's Overall Growth

China will allow all couples to have two children, abandoning its decades-long one-child policy, the Communist Party of China (CPC) announced after a key meeting on Thursday.

The new policy will improve the demographic structure of China, increase labor supply, ease pressure brought by an aging society, facilitate the healthy growth of China's population, and further contribute to the sustainable development of the economy.

According to official data, China had a population of 1.3 billion at the end of 2014, while 15 percent of them were above the age of 60 and 10 percent over the age of 65. China's labor force peaked at 940 million in 2012, dropping to 930 million by 2014. The figure is expected to decrease by another 29 million by 2020. The new plan on Thursday is expected to slow that decline in the long run.

High speed railway line took central stage in Milan at the Expo Milano 2015, where before the world exposition's ending day on Saturday, China left to Italy a legacy of collaboration opportunities. 

High speed railway line is closely related to the China-proposed "Belt and Road" initiative, Wan Jun, Chairman of the Supervisory Board of China Railway Rolling Stock Corporation (CRRC), said in his remarks at a round table dedicated to opportunity collaboration between China and Italy in the sector. 

With 17,000 km high speed railway line, above 60 percent of the global total and extending at pace of 8.2 km each day, China offers huge collaboration potential in particular to countries with a vocation for innovation, such as Italy, Wan went on saying. 

Among the six collaboration projects signed during the expo event, involving important companies and institutions from the two countries, a memorandum of cultural communication was signed between CRRC and Politecnico di Milano, a world-renowned scientific and technological university based in Milan. 

Giuliano Noci, marketing professor at Politecnico di Milano, underlined the importance of the "Belt and Road" initiative, that he defined an "occasion to relaunch a connection which has made the history of the world's economic and technological development."

Authorities in Beijing's suburban Tongzhou District vowed on Thursday that they will close all polluting enterprises in the district by the end of 2017.

Tongzhou has already phased out more than 280 enterprises since 2012, and sources with the district said they plan to close 48 more this year.

Beijing's municipal government has announced that it will move some of its departments to Tongzhou, situated in the city's eastern outskirts, over the coming years as part of a regional development plan.

One person was killed and 13 others injured on Thursday when a stage lighting under construction for a concert by famous pop singer Jolin Tsai collapsed in the city of Nanning.

The accident happened at around 5 p.m. in the Guangxi Sports Center in Nanning, capital of south China's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, when workers were building the structure, according to local government sources. 

One of the injured is in a serious condition while the rest suffered minor injuries.

Tsai's concert was scheduled for Saturday. She took to her microblog to express sadness at the accident.

Chinese Empress and Her Beloved Noodle 

In this episode of Eating on Streets of China, William tastes the dish that won the favor of Empress Dowager Cixi. Rumor has it that she was tough as nails; but when it came to noodles, soft yet firm was how she liked it. What exactly is so special about this seemingly unexceptional dish? Check out this video and see how William comments on it.

status_message:
Two U.S. astronauts on Wednesday ventured outside the International Space Station for the first spacewalk of their careers to service and upgrade the orbital laboratory.

Scott Kelly and Kjell Lindgren from the U.S. space agency NASA started the endeavor at 8:03 a.m. EDT (1203 GMT), which is expected to last six hours and 30 minutes, NASA said. 

The first task for the duo will be to install a thermal cover on the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer, which is a state-of-the-art particle physics detector that has been attached to the station since 2011. 

They will also lubricate the 57.7-foot (15.6-meter) Canadarm2 robotic arm, remove a piece of thermal insulation from a power switching unit, and route power cables for a future docking port. 

This is the 32nd U.S. spacewalk to service the station, but it is the first for both Kelly, who is in the middle of a year-long mission aboard the station, and flight engineer Lindgren. 

Another spacewalk is scheduled for the pair on Nov. 6. in an attempt to restore an ammonia cooling system to its original configuration.

A spacewalk was conducted in November 2012 to try to isolate a leak in the station's cooling supply, but the leak was subsequently traced to a different component.

Dare to Eat Some Rabbit Heads?

Bunny, Bunny, Bunny, so cute and fluffy that you just don't want to stop petting this soft little ball of fur. 
But wait, what if I tell you the head of rabbit is an all-time-favorite food for many Chinese people? 

Lao Ma Rabbit heads were so popular in Sichuan Province, that they've spread out across the country. Today, Beijing has over 80 restaurants serving the dish. William Wang may love rabbits, but will he love eating them?

Beijing Exhibition Reflects on War-time Sexual Crime

An international exhibition about the sexual crimes during the Second World War is now underway in Beijing.

Organizers and artists say they want to use art to reflect on that matter.

The Intimate Transgressions exhibition in the 798 Art District showcases the art works of 35 artists from different countries.
China is making a five-year plan for the nation's economic and social development. It's going to be the 13th Five-Year Plan. This video tells us what a five-year plan is and how it is made.

China Mulls Routine Navigation through Arctic Waters to Europe

Shipping experts are considering routine navigation through Arctic waters to link China and Europe, a shortcut to bypass the route that passes through the Malacca Strait and Suez Canal.

Earlier this month, Chinese vessel Yong Sheng finished a record-setting round trip from Europe to north China by sailing through the Arctic waters of the Northeast Passage and docking at Tianjin Port. 

The cargo ship is the first Chinese merchant ship to sail from Europe to China via the Northeast Passage, an icy path north of Russia and Scandinavia. 

Yong Sheng sailed nearly 20 thousand nautical miles, or over 37 thousand kilometers during the 55-day voyage.

Many experts expect the Arctic passage to become the next "golden waterway" for trade between China and Europe.

Meteorology Park to be Built on Mount Huangshan

China will build its first meteorology park on Mount Huangshan in east China's Anhui Province, the Huangshan Management Committee said on Tuesday. 

Huangshan is well known for its sunrises, winter snow and views from above the clouds, making it an ideal place to build the country's first park featuring meteorological scenes, according to the committee.

#SouthChinaSea Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi has warned the United States not to "make trouble out of nothing", in response to the US Navy's intention of sending a warship within 12 nautical miles of China's islands in the South China Sea. Listen to how our expert thinks China might respond.
