Observers in China are dismissing concerns that marking Memorial Days will lead to a surge of ultra-nationalistic sentiment or fervent anti-Japanese behavior.

There was not much fanfare as China's top legislature approved a bill to mark the end of a war that brought much misery to China, and even less for the date marking the start of a six-week long rampage of slaughter, rape and looting in the country's war-time capital by Japanese troops.

But observers say the bill nonetheless carries weighty consideration as it shows the country's determination to remember its agonizing history.

Dr. Joseph Cheng is a historian at the Baptist University of Hong Kong.

"Marking these important events as a public holiday may well offer opportunities for people to commemorate the occasion, will allow people to discuss and think about the issues concerned. And at this stage it certainly would be a signal to the Japanese government that the Chinese people, the Chinese nation remembers and expects the Japanese people to do the same."

Relations between Japan and its neighbors have been low in recent years.

Aside from escalating tension over territorial disputes with China and South Korea, the current Japanese cabinet also treaded on some facts associated with the Second World War.

There have been denials of the war-time sex slave issue, and school text books have been changed in an effort to reinforce Japan's territorial claims.

Cheng says observing remembrance days could actually ease tension between China and Japan.

"There is such a danger, but at the same time, even without designating the day as a public holiday, we do understand that provocative acts on the part of Japan may well cause adverse feelings and anger among Chinese people leading to protest activities." 

Dr. Cheng reiterated that marking the two occasions engages the Chinese nation in self-reflection, and Japan as the perpetrators during the war have more reasons to do the same.

Professor Lam Kai Yin, a Sino-Japanese relation specialist at the City University of Hong Kong, while voicing a similar opinion, said as a legalized national policy the act does obligate the government to explain to the people what is expected of them.

"The Chinese government does have the obligation to explain to the Chinese people that the two memorial days are set for people to reflect on the human tragedy of war and its consequences, and reflect on why they should not have happened in the first place."

On a very positive note, Prof. Lam said possibilities should not be excluded that the Japanese nation could be able to follow the example of the Germans and friendship with China be fully restored.

(The article is originally written by Su Yi, a CRI reporter.)
link_name: Marking Memorial Days Won't Cause Ultra-nationalistic Sentiment

status_message:
The 75-day Occupy Central  protests in Hong Kong ended peacefully Thursday and Hong Kong authorities cleared Occupy sites in Admiralty and got traffic in front of the government headquarters moving again before midnight. But no side can claim victory and the result is what can be expected by resorting to intentional violations of the local law and regulations, albeit with a touch of the civil disobedience spirit. 

The clearance followed injunction orders issued by the High Court of Hong Kong. Monitored by members of the police watchdog and more than 200 local and international journalists, the seven-hour police operation proceeded without any clashes between officers and protesters, unlike in the clearance operation in Mong Kok. The police ended the main sit-in of the Occupy movement in Admiralty Thursday with the arrest of 247 people, including politicians, student leaders and a pop star.  Dramatically, more than 100 protesters had started a sit-in on the road, waiting to be arrested including such local household names as Democratic Party founding chairman Martin Lee Chu-ming, Apple Daily boss Jimmy Lai Chee-ying, Canto-pop singer Denise Ho Wan-see, Federation of Students secretary general Alex Chow Yong-kang and nine members of the federation.

Hong Kong Chief Executive C.Y. Leung had ordered police to continue using minimal force in the clearance of both the Admiralty and Causeway Bay Occupy camps and appealed to his fellow lawmakers to put aside their differences to support Hong Kong's long-term interests. But students vowed to fight on, predicting a 'second wave of occupation' in other ways after Christmas.

A Hong Kong government spokesman has said the occupation was a "severe blow to the economy, politics, society and people's livelihood". To make matters worse, a serious question now arises as to whether Hong Kong could still be governed effectively.
link_name: Hong Kong's Occupy Central  protests end with no winners

status_message:
With the announcement that five health care workers will share Time Magazine's 2014 Person of the Year award, the fight against Ebola in West Africa has once again captured the headlines of mainstream media in the world. The role played by major countries including the United States and China has also become a hot topic bringing about both compliments and complaints. But at this critical time of crisis, it is more constructive to make proposals for improvement instead of pointing fingers.

The latest figure from the World Health Organization indicates that the death toll from the Ebola outbreak in West Africa has risen to 6,331 in the three worst hit countries. In Sierra Leone only, between 80 and 100 new cases of Ebola are being reported every day and the country desperately needs more than 1,000 beds to treat victims. Washington has led the international drive to stop the spread of the disease, sending thousands of troops and making donation commitments. The White House is now asking Congress for $6.18 billion in additional funding to fight Ebola, which includes calls for more than $4.5 billion for the immediate response to the disease and $1.5 billion for a contingency fund to make resources available if necessary. Earlier in late October, the White House responded to criticism that as the global superpower it was not doing enough by taking a veiled swipe at the contributions of Russia and China. Indeed, the United States' Ebola commitment has dwarfed Beijing's 750 million yuan ($123 million) in aid. Some critics have rounded on Beijing for being "mercantilistic " and not helping more in Africa's hour of need. There are even suggestions that the local African roads and infrastructure China has helped build may have hastened the Ebola crisis by bringing infected animals into closer contact with humans. 

But mere criticism will not help ease the crisis. In fact, China has promised that its assistance will not stop until the Ebola epidemic is eradicated in West Africa. Since August, China has made four rounds of emergency funding to the international effort against the Ebola virus epidemic, and dispatched hundreds of aid workers to Africa to combat Ebola including health experts and medical staff. China has announced that a medical squad of the People's Liberation Army, which has experience from a 2002 outbreak of SARS, will build a 100-bed treatment center in Liberia and 480 PLA medical staff will be deployed to treat Ebola patients. It's the first time China has deployed a whole unit of epidemic prevention forces and military medical staff abroad. In addition, some Chinese companies in West Africa have also joined the relief efforts. 

China is Africa's biggest trade partner. In fact, more than half of China's foreign aid of over $14 billion went to Africa. China was dispatching more health personnel as aid groups from the United States, Europe, and Japan were evacuating their own. The U.S. military isn't the only institution capable of building emergency response centers and staffing them. There are suggestions that China can use its huge transport and communication capabilities in Africa to distribute supplies and public messaging, especially given its large number of construction firms in the region. U.S. and Chinese troops staged their first disaster relief exercise in November 2013 in a signal that China is increasingly eager to use its growing military muscle for humanitarian causes. 

Domestically since the Ebola virus is transmitted through contact with bodily fluids, quarantine measures — widely used in China's fight against avian flu — can help break the chain of infection. Given that early symptoms of Ebola infection are similar to those of H7N9, China's experience in handling these cases can be useful to Ebola treatment. Despite their lack of experience in handling Ebola cases, Chinese doctors have reportedly identified the Ebola virus antibody gene, along with diagnostic reagents for the virus. And by the end of August, China surprised the world by announcing that it had successfully developed its first drug for treating Ebola. But China has not completed the building of a maximum containment laboratory known as a BSL-4 facility to handle highly dangerous pathogens such as the Ebola viruses. Given the lack of basic research on the virus, it is highly doubtful that China's first Ebola drug can be effective — so far, it has only been allowed for use in "emergency situations."  Even the United States — which owns at least 7 BSL-4 labs and has spent the past three decades researching the virus — is still in the experimental stages of developing vaccines and post-exposure treatment for Ebola.

So while the Chinese role in helping African countries fight Ebola should not be downplayed, there will be a limit on how much China can contribute to the ongoing humanitarian efforts in Africa.
link_name: How much more can China contribute to fighting Ebola

status_message:
The new air purifier announced by Chinese electronics company Xiaomi Inc. is a coup designed to steal the limelight from international manufacturers of similar products. The Mi Air Purifier is equipped with real time air quality monitor and its tiny tower takes up only about A4 paper size space on the floor. But most importantly, the machine has a price tag of just 899 yuan ($145), much cheaper than smart air purifiers made by others. 

Air purifiers are gradually becoming a must-have home appliance in Beijing and elsewhere in many parts of China, where smog levels have stayed at hazardous levels from time to time. At this price/performance ratio, consumers really have little to complain about. 

Often described as "China's Apple", Xiaomi is now the third-largest smartphone manufacturer in the world behind Samsung and Apple. In selling the Xiaomi smartphone, Xiaomi employs a strategy that prices the phone almost at bill-of-material prices. To profit from the narrow margin, Xiaomi sells a model for up to 18 months instead of the short 6 months used by other manufacturers to profit from the fall in the costs of components that occurs over time. Other than that, Xiaomi is also known as borrowing design from other companies, and offering a competitively-priced product with decent quality. But air purifier is not as high-tech a product as a smartphone. So such a business model does not seem to apply here. Can it deliver this time? Xiaomi's chief executive officer Lei Jun says his company wants to contribute to society by selling the product at such a low price. His remark is tremendously impressive.
link_name: Xiaomi stages a coup with Mi Air Purifier

status_message:
"Progress is impossible without change,
and those who cannot change their minds
cannot change anything."

"Just do what must be done.
This may not be happiness,
but it is greatness."

"People who say it cannot be done
should not interrupt those who are doing it."

"When I was young,
I observed that nine out of ten things I did
were failures.
So I did ten times more work."

"Better keep yourself clean and bright;
you are the window through
which you must see the world."

"A life spent making mistakes
is not only more honorable,
but more useful than a life
spent doing nothing."

"We have no more right to consume happiness
without producing it
than to consume wealth
without producing it."

"Life isn't about finding yourself.
Life is about creating yourself."

"The reasonable man adapts himself to the world;
the unreasonable one persists in trying
to adapt the world to himself."

"There are two tragedies in life.
One is not to get your heart's desire.
The other is to get it."

"We are made wise
not by the recollection of our past,
but by the responsibility for our future."

~ George Bernard Shaw (26 July 1856 – 2 November 1950) was an Irish playwright who wrote more than 60 plays. He was also an essayist, novelist and short story writer. Nearly all his writings address prevailing social problems with a vein of comedy which makes their stark themes more palatable.

https://twitter.com/CRImobile/status/542312486750281728
Chinese President Xi Jinping welcomes Irish President Michael D. Higgins in Beijing

The conventional wisdom is that we should not overemphasize the significance that the benchmark Shanghai index regained the 3,000-point psychological mark on Monday, the first time since April 25, 2011. But from a symbolic standpoint, it's still a major indicator for the Chinese economic outlook in the long run.  

The public interest in China's stock market has been growing steadily with the rapid rise in stock indices. For punters and stock enthusiasts, to say that Chinese stocks are on a tear would be an understatement. The post-June rally gathered steam after breaking key down trendlines in July and October. More recently, the up-move accelerated further following the opening of the Shanghai stock market to foreign investment. The rally was also supported by interest rate cut, which increased liquidity. Since the Chinese central bank cut interest rates on Nov. 21, the Shanghai index has surprised the market with a 17 percent jump. Many institutions expect a cut in the reserve requirement ratio soon for some banks, which is expected to release more funds into the equity market. Many analysts view the rally as the beginning of a bullish cycle. The Composite has shown its largest 6-day, 6-week and 6-month gains in roughly 5 years. Some experts good at stock market technical analysis have explained that when a market breaks out of a low-volatility compression like the Shanghai Composite has recently, it typically moves to a high-volatility extreme, eventually, despite profit taking to take advantage of a sharp rise in the stock price.

But as always for stock market analysis, there is an equally convincing bearish argument that the recent stock gains are the result of irrational buying, amplified by borrowed money and don't reflect the nation's economic fundamentals. Skeptics have predicted that if the central bank shifted course in easing, China's stock market rally would fizzle away very quickly.

Actually it's not that important to ask whether the rally has run its course or there could be more to this move, especially for long-term investors. What's important is that the Chinese stock market has become gradually normal and attractive to ordinary investors. For quite a long time, most of China's private equity buyers have lost interest in the stock market, because the performance of stock market seemed to have nothing to do with the country's general economic conditions. To some extent, the Chinese stock market was more an arena for companies to raise cash and a gambling house than one for investment. 

But the abnormal performance of stocks could be a reflection on China's general economic state. Since 1978, China has seen the most rapid economic growth of any country in world history, and the most rapid growth of living standards of any major economy. China is now the world's fastest-growing major economy, with growth rates averaging 10 percent over the past 30 years. American business magnate Bill Gates recently made a mind-blowing comparison in his blog that between 2011 and 2013, China consumed 6.6 gigatons of concrete – that's more than the U.S. used in the entire 20th century. Common sense tells us that this unprecedented and phenomenal growth cannot possibly grow forever. Some economists now talk more about the nature of China's economic slowdown, believing that the country is having a soft landing with the potential to maintain an average economic growth of above 7 percent a year for another decade. 

In a word, China's economic growth has at last become normalized and the current stock market may just be a reflection of the positive view on China. Apparently the outlook is more optimistic for investors with a longer-term horizon. Chinese premier Li Keqiang has promised to focus on boosting reform and making structural adjustment to ensure that the market will play a strong role. This principle applies to stock market as well. In the future, the hand of government will surely become less and less visible with market forces determining the rise and fall of stocks.  

The stock market is the barometer of economic development. Historically it has been proven true with the wisdom of hindsight. There should be no exception to the rule for China's stock market.
link_name: The importance of China's stock market becoming normal

status_message:
The current fresh-water crisis in the Maldives has aroused worldwide attention with China and other countries lending a helping hand for the emergency. But apparently more needs to be done for a long-term solution. 

In fact, as early as in 2012, 90 percent of the atoll's population already depended on rain water, often collected in household water tanks as a principal source of water. However, the rain water storage is limited with an average household storage capacity of 2500 liters on most islands. It is simply amazing they hadn't had a crisis earlier, as the reduced rainfall during the dry season (January-June) leaves several islands across Maldives in a severe annual water crisis. The problem has been compounded by changing weather patterns and prolonged dry periods. 

China is on good terms with the Indian Ocean archipelago. Maldives is among the hottest destinations for Chinese tourists. Chinese President Xi Jinping made a state visit to Maldives in September, the first of its kind since the two sides established diplomatic ties 42 years ago. The two countries reached an agreement on the development of the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road. In response to an appeal from the Maldives for aid from India, Sri Lanka, the United States and China, the Chinese government is shipping about 1,000 tons fresh water to the water-starved country via plane and vessel and has arranged for all commercial flights out of China to the Maldives capital of Male to be loaded with drinking water. In addition, a Chinese navy ship with water purification facilities is on its way to Male. At the same time, the Chinese government has donated 500,000 U.S. dollars to the Maldives government to speed up repairs in a desalination plant and restore water to the capital. Earlier Maldives announced that an estimated 20 million U.S. dollars would be needed to repair the plant that was damaged in a fire last week resulting in the capital's population of 130,000 being without water. India is also sending five planes with water and two ships with parts that can help fix the machinery at the plant.

Efforts are being made to provide sustainable solutions to the annual water crisis inclduign several internationally funded projects initiated over the past years. The Maldives Ministry of Housing and Environment and the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) signed a US$8.5 million project in 2011 to provide "climate smart freshwater solutions" to three densely populated islands; Ihavandho in Haa Alif atoll, Mahibadhoo in Alif Dhaalu atoll and Gadhdhoo in Gaafu Dhaalu. The United States government also provided US$7.1 million towards an integrated water resource system on Lhaviyani Hinnavaru and Haa alif Dhihdhoo islands, under an agreement signed in 2011 between the two governments.  Hopefully the latest crisis will help bring more concrete measures that will go beyond being merely discussed at policy level and have more sustainability.
link_name: Maldives water crisis calls for a more sustainable solution

As part of the 2014 China-South Africa Year activities, a global tour of an oil painting named 'Mandela' was showcased at Beijing's 798 Art District on Nov 25, to commemorate Nelson Mandela. The painting, which is 30 meters long and 3.3 meters high, was created by artist Li Bin over two years.

The painting will also be exhibited in Hong Kong, Taiwan and other regions from July 18 next year, and will finally end its tour in South Africa.

A new set of books have been released in China documenting the Nanjing Massacre.

The books come in three sets, and include 5 volumes each. They include letters and documents collected from Japanese army officers, as well as accounts from survivors, along with media reports from neutral sources.

Wang Weixing is the director of the Institute of History at the Jiangsu Provincial Academy of Social Sciences.

"The Japanese eyewitness accounts in these books admitted that 40,000 to 50,000 Chinese were killed in the Nanjing Massacre: this casualty count is by far the biggest number we've seen in historical materials from the Japanese side."

Confusion at the time of the Nanjing Massacre, which began in late 1937 during the height of Japan's invasion of China, has created a wide gap in the estimates of the number of people killed, with figures ranging anywhere from 40-thousand to upward of 300-thousand.

The release of the new books comes ahead of the first Nanjing Massacre memorial day to be held here in China on December 13th.
link_name: Popular Reader of Historical Studies on Nanjing Massacre Released

Chinese carmakers produced 10 times as many new-energy vehicles last month as they did in November 2013, thanks to intense government-led promotion.

The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology says a total of about 9,700 green vehicles were made last month.

For the first 11 months of this year, total production rose fivefold to more than 56,700 units. New-energy vehicles include pure electric cars and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles.
Intense government-led promotion has introduced more new-energy vehicles to China's roads as the country aims to save energy and combat pollution.

A raft of measures has been put into place, including tax exemptions, subsidies for car purchases, and requirements for government bodies to buy green cars.

Last month, the Ministry of Finance unveiled new carrots for building charging facilities for new-energy vehicles in cities.

A documentary "Today in the History of War against Japanese Aggression" is set to be aired both in China and abroad starting January 1st next year.

The 365-episode series is co-productioned by China Radio International and China Archives. It chronicles the history of the wars with audio, videos and historic documents. Seventy percent of the materials are being revealed for the first time in Chinese history.

The documentary will be aired on multiple media platforms.

A press conference on the documentary was held at China Radio International. CRI director-general Wang Gengnian, deputy director-general Xia Jixuan and China

Archives bureau chief Yang dongquan attended and delivered speeches at the conference.
link_name: Documentary on War against Japanese Aggression to be Aired

December 3 marks the 73rd anniversary of China Radio International (CRI).  

CRI was founded on December 3, 1941. It is China's state-level radio station that broadcasts worldwide (to a global audience) in 65 languages. CRI aims to introduce China to the rest of the world, introduce the world to China, report global affairs to the world and promote understanding and friendship between the Chinese and people from other countries. It adheres to the journalistic tenets of reporting from the Chinese perspective with a world vision and a global dimension. CRI goes to great lengths to be a modern, comprehensive and innovative international media group.

December 3, 1941
It was during China's War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression. From a cave in Yan'an in northwestern China, the voice of Japanese-Chinese announcer Hara Kiyosi marked the beginning of China's overseas broadcasting.

Over 50% of Locks in China Can Be Broken Open in Seconds

The China Consumers' Association has warned that A-locks, which constitute over 50 percent of all locks used on the mainland, are extremely susceptible to break-ins.

An A-lock refers to locks where the keyhole resembles the English letter "I" or an "X." These locks generally lack internal pins or a mechanism with grooves inside that would make them harder to unlock without a key.

With today's lock-picking tools and training, anyone can overcome an A-lock in just a couple of seconds, according to the association.

B-locks, on the other hand, are more complex in design, with the groove and pin mechanisms that make it harder to unlock via lock-picking. The time it takes to open a B-lock without a key is about 30 minutes, according to the China Consumer's Association.

Residents and business owners using A-locks are urged to switch to B-locks or other high-security locks immediately.

People can improve their lock's security by just changing the cylinder, rather than the whole lock itself. A B-lock cylinder costs between 200 and 300 yuan ($US32.50 to $US49).

http://english.cri.cn/12394/2014/12/02/2743s854780.htm

By Xu Qinduo

     The fiasco of the ruling KMT party in Taiwan's district elections is seen by many as a "No" signal from the people of the island to Ma Ying-jeou's government's current conciliatory policy toward the mainland. If that's the case, will the victory of the opposing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) damage peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait?

    The defeat suffered by the KMT reveals Taiwanese discontent toward the unsatisfactory status quo on the island — the growing gap between rich and poor, stagnation in wages and the lack of employment opportunities for young people. The unexpected recent food security scandals also worked against the ruling party's candidates.

    The media tend to depict Ma as friendly to the mainland and simplify his policy as pro-mainland. But that's far from accurate.

    It's true that Ma advocates peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait because he understands that Taiwan wouldn't be able to bear strains in its relations with Beijing.

    A services trade pact between Taiwan and the mainland, pending ratification, is controversial, as reflected by protests and the occupation of government buildings in March.

    But Ma's government acts solely for the interests of Taiwan.

    Since 2008, when Ma was first elected as the island's leader, Taiwan has strengthened trade ties with the mainland. The two sides signed multiple trade deals, including the landmark Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) in 2010. Partly boosted by tariff reductions under the ECFA, Taiwan now exports 25 percent of its products to the mainland.

    In addition to a services trade pact waiting to be approved by Taiwan's legislature, Taiwan and the mainland are also negotiating an agreement on goods trade. All of these are designed to lift Taiwan's economy out of a state of slow growth.

    Can the DPP do a better job in improving people's livelihoods? Hardly, unless they take practical steps to keep the sound relationship with the mainland on track.

    For the existing deals, the DPP will find it impossible to roll them back since they are designed to benefit Taiwan more than the mainland.

    There are even more imminent challenges for Taiwan when the mainland and South Korea Free Trade Agreement (FTA) takes effect next year.

    According to Taiwan's official figures, about 80 percent of their exports to the mainland market are competing with those from South Korea. An FTA between Seoul and Beijing will put Taiwan at a great disadvantage. It would be wise for Taiwan, whether under the KMT or the DPP, to forge a close relationship with the mainland in order to maintain its competitive edge.

    The Chinese mainland is reshaping the financial landscape of Asia with a series of new business initiatives, such as Asia Infrastructure Investment Bank, FTA in Asia and the Pacific, the Silk Road Economic Belt, the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road, etc. Taiwan needs to leap on these historic changes to avoid marginalization; it should seize upon the opportunity to inject fresh vitality into its ailing economy.

    Politically, Asian countries will frown upon any DPP moves that threaten to destroy stability in the region. Similarly, even the U.S. would not be amused if the DPP dares to rock the boat.

    With the DPP's landslide victory, Beijing will have to deal with the pro-independence party whether they like it or not, but that doesn't mean a total regression of the harmony across the strait unless the DPP plans to perpetuate economic stagnation and isolate Taiwan's economy.

    (The author is a current affairs commentator with China Radio International.)
link_name: Will DPP's victory sabotage cross-Strait stability?

What is special about this annual journey is that 39-year-old Liu Lingchao carries his own self-made tent throughout the journey.

Liu Lingchao refused anyone's help, even a bottle of water or a cigarette and also declined to take lifts from other vehicles along the way, local media reported. He also took a bucket and some kitchenware along with his 'house' to meet his basic needs.

【Zou Beats "Mini-Manny" to Challenge Belt】

Chinese Olympic gold medallist boxer Zou Shiming knocked down Kwanpichit Onesongchaigym of Thailand three times Sunday at a 12-round flyweight contest, which earned him a world champion shot.

This was a final eliminator for the WBO world flyweight championship, making Zou mandatory challenger to title holder Juan Francisco Estrada of Mexico in a fight likely to take place in spring next year in Macau.

Zou, who won gold medals in the Beijing and London Olympics, dominated the fight most of the way, but his Thai opponent, dubbed "Mini-Manny", never stopped coming forward and the two engaged in some good exchanges late in the fight that had the sellout crowd cheering at the final bell. Fighting for only the sixth time as a pro, Zou was cut over his left eye by an apparent head butt in the middle rounds and had to deal with an opponent who tried everything he could to overcome a talent and strength advantage.

【China to Open Civil Aviation Markets】

China has decided to open its civil aviation markets in 2015, allowing private aircraft to fly in airspace under 1,000 meters without permissions from the military.

China's Civil Aviation Administration estimates that around 500,000 civil pilots should be trained to meet the market demands by 2035, while the number stands at thousands at present in the country.

The policy change comes on the heels of the country's determination to boost infrastructure, in a bid to buoy the cooling economy.

It is reported that over 200 aviation companies are applying for business licenses to operate in the new market.

The affluent are also waiting for their own private jets that can fly over the sky.

As pilot schools may launch programs to train civil pilots, oversea institutions are also looking to join hands with Chinese partners, offering new programs that may cost some 100,000 U.S. dollars.

Besides training more professionals, some of the programs will also focus on rich people who wish to fly their own jets.

China's current training system can only produce 100 pilots a year.

Industry insiders say that Beijing will publish a detailed regulation on the newly-opened aviation market by the end of this year.

They also hold high hopes that the country will further open its airspace to 3,000 meters in 2020.

【Lenovo to Bring Moto 360 to China】

A senior manager at #Lenovo has confirmed that #Motorola Mobility, now a wholly-owned subsidiary of Lenovo, will return to China with products that include the Moto X smartphone and the Moto 360 #smartwatch.

Zhang Hui, vice president of Lenovo, has told Sina.com.cn that the Moto franchise, including Moto X, Moto G and Moto 360, as well as Motorola Droid, will target a high-end market when Motorola comes back to China.

The former mobile phone star lost its Chinese market to other smartphone makers such as Samsung and Apple. It laid off about 1,000 R&D and technical Chinese employees last year.

But with the recent US$2.91 billion acquisition by local tech giant Lenovo, the Motorola brand is seeking a revival under Lenovo's dual-brand strategy.

According to Zhang Hui, the Moto and Lenovo brands will target high-end and lower-end markets respectively, separated by a 3,000-yuan retail price.

Lenovo has set up a sales team for Moto's China comeback, although no timetable has been announced.

On October 30, Lenovo chairman and CEO Yang Yuanqing announced the completion of acquiring Motorola Mobility from Google.

【Who Should be Responsible for Weird Landmark Buildings?】

Many #strange-shaped and expensive #landmark buildings built around China have triggered heated public criticism in recent years.

A recent online survey pointed out that over 80 percent of respondents believe that decision makers and approvers are responsible for China's many odd landmark buildings, according to China Youth Daily.

Of all the 9,254 respondents, 63 percent admitted that there were weird landmark buildings in their respective cities or provinces.

Why are there so many weird buildings?

About 73 percent of respondents believe that these buildings were designed in odd fashion just to get attention, while 46 percent thought the weird designs were erected to hide something, of which the public would otherwise disapprove.

But who should be blamed for these buildings?

According to the survey, 81 percent of respondents said the decision makers and approvers should take responsibility, while others blame designers or property developers.

Feng Guochuan, chief designer at Zhubo Design Corporation, said: "Some officials and property owners love to give opinions on designs. And these amateurs' intervention is the direct cause of these weird landmark buildings."

Cheng Taining, director of Architectural Design and Theoretical Research Center of Southeast University, agreed with Feng. He pointed out that the design would be changed until the official in charge of the building is satisfied.

What do people feel about these buildings in general?

The poll revealed that 87 percent of respondents feel disgusted about these buildings because of the structures' extremely high price tag. A designer in Shenzhen explained that sometimes the walls and roofs were designed to be curved in order to have an attractive shape, which would greatly increase construction costs.
link_name: Photos from China Plus News's post

【Watching over Fallen Comrades】

In 1980, Chen Jungui was dispatched with a team of soldiers to build roads in the Tianshan Mountains. The team was snowed in by a blizzard. As their food ran out, team leader Zheng Linshu sent them in different directions to find help. All died except for Chen.

For nearly 30 years, Chen, 55, has stayed with the tombs of his team members. Chen credited his survival to the team's last small bun, given him by team leader Zheng.

After recovering from the ordeal, Chen left his hometown in Liaoning province in 1985 and returned to the valleys in the Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region with his wife, Sun Liqin, and newborn son. They had decided to watch over the tombs of his fellow soldiers.

Over the past decades, Chen and his wife have been the first to arrive at the tombs each day, cleaning them and paying tribute to the dead, who he believes should be remembered for their sacrifice. He sought out the families of each team member, but when he learned the whereabouts of Zheng's parents, he only found their graves in Hubei province. At their gravesite, he vowed he would stay with Zheng's tomb for the rest of his life so as "not to leave Zheng lonely".

status_message:
Biggest toxic dog meat scandal heard in Zhejiang 

In one of the biggest cases of its kind, 17 men have been charged with selling poison-laden dog meat in East China's Zhejiang Province on Monday, Ningbo Daily reported on Tuesday.

It is reportedly the largest amount of poisonous dog meat ever found to be sold in Zhejiang, with 38 tons of meat purchased by a single dealer. The men were charged at Fenghua People's Court.

Between 2012 and August 2013 the seven members killed 95 dogs in Zhejiang's Ningbo City by poisoning them with cyanide or shooting them with anesthetic needles, mostly bought online, the court heard.

status_message:
Little Calabash Brother goes viral!

Photos of a ＃toddler dressed up as Chinese ＃cartoon characters, the ＃CalabashBrothers, by her mother have gone viral online. 

Weibo user @yiliermilier, the toddler's mother, dressed her daughter ＃Miko into seven different styles of the cartoon characters, and posted the photos online.

Netizens exclaimed "＃lovely" and praised the ＃cute ＃kid with the ＃chubby face. Some said the pictures reminded them of their childhood, when they used to watch the show on TV.

The Supreme People's Court says former domestic security chief Zhou Yongkang's case is under investigation by the central government and they have not got any information about the case entering legal proceedings.

New online horizons 

China's biggest gathering of #Internet-tech pros began in Beijing on Tuesday. The annual China Internet Conference is discussing the latest trends in internet-based technology.

High speed #4G networks, #ecommerce, and online education are the hot topics at this year's conference. The conference aims to create new opportunities in technology in China.

4G has finally arrived in China

No more lengthy waiting times for movies to download onto your phone! That's the promise from Miao Wei, China's minister of Industry and Information. He confirmed the government is backing the development of 4G in China.

New payment methods

Who needs cash or cards? Finger-printing might soon be the new thing in China. A number of companies say they're developing fingerprint payment methods. To promote the developments they offered a 72-hour cash-less shopping experience, where participants could get a feel for the future of finance. 

Internet Education

One firm talked about new online software that could change the way that education is delivered in China. Using the application students can take multiple choice exams, and the software is able to point out where they need to put in more effort.

Hefty discounts in China's strained homes market for online shoppers 

China #Vanke Co., the largest residential real estate developer in China, has teamed up with #Alibaba, the country's ecommerce giant to offer discounts to home buyers that shop at #Taobao.com, Alibaba's online shopping site.

According to a statement on Taobao's website, consumers who have spent more than 2 million yuan ($325,000) on Taobao.com in the last year will get a discount of 2 million yuan when purchasing a home sold by Vanke.

The same deal applies to any who have purchased between fifty thousand ($8,131) to 2 million yuan ($325,000) worth of online products from Taobao; a discount is offered equal to the cost of purchases. A smaller discount of fifty thousand yuan is granted for anyone spending less, but more than one yuan.

According to the statement homes from a number of cities including Beijing and Hangzhou are covered in this offer. The offer started Aug. 25 and will last until Sept. 30.

The Five Reasons Why China Works: fifth, minyi versus minxin. Behind all the above is the Chinese philosophy of governance, including, inter alia, the two distinctive concepts: minyi and minxin, the former referring to "public opinion", and the latter to "the hearts and minds of the people" (approximate English translation), which was first put forward by Mencius (372 - 289 BC). 

http://english.cri.cn/6909/2014/03/12/2821s817101_2.htm

The Five Reasons Why China Works: fourth, development administration. It's not far from wrong to claim that China has created its own model of development, an important feature of which can be called "development adminstration," in contrast to public administration.

http://english.cri.cn/6909/2014/03/12/2821s817101_2.htm

The Five Reasons Why China Works: third, demand creation. The fact that China has been able to sustain an annual GDP growth rate of over 9 percent for over three decades is inseparable from these regular and predictable cycles of expectation and demand creation.

http://english.cri.cn/6909/2014/03/12/2821s817101_2.htm
link_name: The Five Reasons Why China Works

We Want You!

Do you have an interest in Chinese Cuisine and a gastronomic sense of daring? We welcome any foreigners in Beijing to join our Chinese Cooking Callenge.

Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Chopsticks-Beyond/459550544113444

Website: http://english.cri.cn/6566/2013/04/23/Zt1261s761234.htm

To celebrate the 15th anniversary of CRIENGLISH.com, the official English-language Website of China Radio International, we have launched a special program: Chopsticks & Beyond.

We are inviting foreign cooking enthusiasts to join our Chinese cooking competition. Each month starting in June, 2013, the competition will focus on one of China's four great culinary traditions - Sichuan Cuisine, Cantonese Cuisine, Shandong Cuisine or Huaiyang Cuisine. Professional chefs will give guidance to the contestants. Judges will be popular food microbloggers and professionals from the World Association of Chinese Cuisine (WACC).

The winning dish needs a dash pizzazz, either in its ingredients, inspiration or display. An influence from your home country is recommended. There will be prizes for each month's winner.

NBA player Jason Collins comes out as gay

Washington Wizards center Jason Collins has come out as the first openly gay active athlete in one of the big-four American team sports.

The NBA veteran center made the announcement in an interview with Sports Illustrated, published on Monday.

Collins, who played with the Boston Celtics and Washington Wizards this season is now a free agent.

The 34-year-old has played for six teams in the NBA and reached the NBA finals twice.

He says he intends to continue in the sport.
